title: Software firm Innovation bought by Carlyle for £500m
text:

Sat, Aug 29, 2015, 04:00 BST - UK Markets closed Software firm Innovation bought by Carlyle for £500m By Andrew Trotman | Telegraph – 2 hours 23 minutes ago 0.00 
The UK company employs more than 3,000 staff in this country 
Innovation , the London-listed software company, is to be bought by US buyout firm Carlyle for just under £500m. 
The 40p-a-share offer values Innovation, which provides services to help insurers process claims, at a 13.5pc premium to the stock’s closing price on Thursday. 
In a statement released on Friday night, Innovation said that although there is scope to grow the business further, its directors “recognise the benefits ... in having a partner like Carlyle with [a] global presence”. 
The UK company, which employs more than 3,000 staff in this country, has grown dramatically in the past few years, boosting its market capitalisation from just £50m in 2009 to £433m today. 
The company was founded by Rob Terry, who also started outsourcer Quindell (Xetra: M6FA.DE - news ) . The business is now run by chief executive Andy Roberts, who is in line for a windfall following the sale. 
“Carlyle brings a commitment and vision to the ongoing investment requirements of the business, providing Innovation with enhanced financial and operational flexibility as the group seeks to execute its strategy in the longer-term,” David Thorpe, non-executive chairman of Innovation, said. 
News (Other OTC: NWSAL - news ) of the deal was first reported by Sky (Amsterdam: BK8.AS - news ) News .
